reviews.review:
Half-Life Blue Shift is an expansion for the original Half-Life. It takes place during Black Mesa Incident and around the same time as Gordon Freeman's introduction to the facility. In this you play as Barney Calhoun, a regular security officer at Black Mesa who's main goal is to escape the facility with everyone else. Although, it is short (around 2-3 hours average for first timers) it provides a decent amount of content for the money.

Pros:-
->Experience through the perspective of someone other than Freeman.
->New Locations.
->New Armor system.
->Some interesting takes on the events of Freeman from og Half-Life
->Great side-story
->Everything else that made Half-Life great.
->Little to no bugs.
->Satisfying Ending.

Cons:-
->A bit on the shorter side.
->No new enemies.
->No new weapons
->No Boss Battles

Highly Recommended for Half-Life fans such as myself. It is not recommended for players that are seeking solely for new content, just like there was in Opposing Force expansion. You will be disappointed.
Неплохое DLC(если его можно так назвать) к оригинальной халве. Конечно сюжет тут простенький, приближенный к какой-то аркаде, но вполне играбельно. За 10 гривасей можно и купить

Blue Shift is an expansion for Half-Life that feels like a sightly higher quality than average level pack you'd find on ModDB from 2007.

Remember the platforming sections in Half-Life? Blue Shift remembers.
Remember when headcrabs were placed around corners and in small tight spaces to get a jumpscare on you? Blue Shift remembers.
Remember that sequence in Blast Pit where you had to press buttons and solve elementary puzzles and backtrack a bit to proceed? Blue Shift remembers.

And that's literally all this expansion has constantly on a repeat for 2 hours. Except in the original game, all of those mechanics were tied to memorable set pieces. Not so much in Blue Shift. Headcrabs are placed around literally every corner on some levels. The puzzles seem like what could be a simplistic engine tech demo/proof of concept, except they are so uninspired I can't imagine them being impressive or memorable even back in 2001, less so several years later.

Even more so, the enemy placement is straight up awful from a game design standpoint. Hitscan opponents show up in places with minimal or no cover, forcing you to take damage. Headcrabs are located around EVERY corner (I really cannot emphasize this enough, it's literally every corner). Vortigaunts teleport straight in front of you and if you are going through the level fast enough, during the 2 hours of game there is, I still managed to get telefragged on 3 separate occassions.

⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀[b]Play Me![/b]

Another great expansion to the Half-Life series. Yes, its a little short and they don't add a whole lot to the half life series like Opposing Force did, but that doesn't take away from how good this is. It has very fun puzzles, things that made me laugh at myself when I figured out what to do because it was usually so simple and right in front of me, yet the way half life does some of these puzzles are very clever. Story was quite simple and too the point, but once again they let you figure out whats happening in the world instead of telling you.  I simply wanted more, had fun, and that is always the sign of a good game to me. 

Beautifully done, Half-Life 20 years later still is fun and a must play franchise, and these games have aged very well.

Blue Shift tiene lugar durante el mismo período de tiempo que Half-Life. Empiezas yendo a trabajar como lo harías cualquier otro día, pero las cosas rápidamente salen mal en Black Mesa. De repente estás bajo asedio, y como miembro de la fuerza de seguridad, tiene la tarea de defender a los científicos de la instalación de los extraterrestres y también de los soldados del gobierno, que han venido a ayudarlo. En la práctica, atravesará el mismo tipo de niveles peligrosos que se encuentran en el juego original. Durante el transcurso de Blue Shift, puedes encontrar un par de referencias inteligentes tanto a Opposing Force como al juego original. Estos, junto con algunos otros chistes, son las partes más divertidas de Blue Shift. El resto consiste en algunos tiroteos bastante directos, una excursión obligatoria a Xen (el universo paralelo de Half-Life), y varios acertijos de salto que logran ser lo suficientemente inteligentes como en lugar de molestos. No se pueden encontrar nuevos desafíos, todo termina muy rápido y no tiene mucho sentido volver a visitar los niveles.

Barney Calhoun, tu personaje en Blue Shift, supuestamente no tiene la misma formación académica que Gordon Freeman, ni tiene el entrenamiento militar del cabo Adrian Shephard, el protagonista de Opposing Force. En el contexto del juego, no hay nada que lo destaque: Barney corre extremadamente rápido (al igual que Gordon y Adrian) y puede sufrir una cantidad excesiva de daño (al igual que Gordon y Adrian). Esto tiene sentido en Half-Life, donde estás protegido por un traje ambiental de última generación, así como en Opposing Force, donde eres un soldado altamente entrenado. En Blue Shift, es una exageración, y la única vez que tienes la sensación de que en realidad se supone que eres un guardia de seguridad realista es en una secuencia temprana en la que debes obtener tu arma y recoger tu chaleco y casco. Al igual que en Half-Life y Opposing Force, tu personaje nunca dice una palabra en el transcurso de Blue Shift. En Half-Life, esto te ayuda a sumergirte en el juego. En Blue Shift, es una lástima. 

Una expansión que no tiene mucho que ofrecer. Aun asi, es un buen juego que merece mi recomendación.

Half-Life: Blue Shift is probably the weakest game in the Half-Life universe, at least when speaking of the original. It didn't add much onto the game play of Half-Life like Opposing Force did. I'd say a majority of this game is puzzles that make very little sense, hence why I have 22 hours for my >>>first playthrough of the game<<<. So many puzzles don't make sense, the shooting is weak and limited, and certain combat scenarios are a pain to get through. HOWEVER, the game is still fun at times, the game's story running parallel with the stories of Freeman and Shepard. If you can get your hands on this game, I'd suggest you do. Just make sure to grab some Advil before you do
Nope

The shortest of the two Half-Life expansions, and unlike Opposing Force, it lacks any new guns or enemies. Nonetheless it's still Half-Life game done proper, and this time you play as Barney Calhoun, a security guard that would later make a reappearance in the sequel.

The premise is same as usual, you come to Black Mesa, bad things happen, now you gotta run for it. The plot is so much more straightforward, there's no detours to launch a rocket or deal with other problem like that. Hence the shorter length. Here it's, just, like, you come to work, appreciate the disfunctional infrastructure of Black Mesa before alien poop hits the fan, then traverse some areas until you learn of old teleportation system prototype, rescue the scientist who knows hot to operate it, get a short trip to Xen and to return power to the thing, and then you dash for it. Overall you get, like, 6 weapons total over duration of entire expansion, and there is no HEV suit - you only got guard vests and helmets to salvage. That's a nice detail to be honest, there are HEV chargers all over the place but since you don't have the suit they are useless.

I probably would recommend AGAINST buying this, but even the default price is 4 euros/dollars tops and it goes down to 39 cents during sale, seemingly the lowest sale price on Steam, definitely worth it!
